key_points: Facebook shut down the pro-Israel 'Jerusalem Prayer Group' page, which had 77 million followers, citing violations of its rules against spam and inauthentic behavior.
The page's founder, Mike Evans, claims the shutdown was due to a "cyber terrorism" campaign by radical Islamic groups who coordinated to flood the page with hate speech and false complaints.
Evans alleges that the campaign involved over a million comments and included anti-Semitic content such as photos of and quotes by Hitler.
Evans, head of the Friends of Zion Association, was informed of the page removal upon arriving in Israel to host a star-studded TV special.
Facebook had previously removed over 200 "fake accounts" for inauthentic behavior in May 2019.
Evans claimed he has not been able to contact Facebook representatives since the page was shut down and that he cannot post to his personal Facebook page.
He has reached out to several politicians, including Sen. Lindsey Graham, Sen. Ted Cruz, Jared Kushner, and former Secretary of State Mike Pompeo for support.
Evans described the page's shutdown as a result of bias and labeled it as "cyber terrorism based upon racism."
A Facebook spokesperson confirmed the page was removed for violating Facebook's rules against spam and inauthentic behavior.
President Biden has reportedly pressured Israel to reduce its military actions in Gaza amid international concerns over the increasing civilian death toll.
